"Historians will record 500 years
from now, I believe, that in the early
part of the twentieth century was
the greatest emancipatory revolution
in the history of the human race,"
said Dr. Charles A. Beard in his final
lecture given under the James Schouler Foundation Tuesday evening.

Dr. Lascelles Abercrombie, the
Hildred Carlisle professor of English
literature at Bedford College, of the
University of London, will deliver the
thirty-first in the series of Percy
Turnbull Memorial Lectures at the
Hopkins during the early part of
April. Dr. Abercrombie will speak on
"The Art of Wordsworth."

"An old era is closed forever, and
we 'are on the threshold of an entirely
new era," the historian said.
Monday he lectured on "History as
Art and Science," pointing out that
historians frequently have made the
mistake of drawing a close analogy
between history and art and science.
Tuesday, talking on "History
Speaks for Itself," Dr. Beard gave
his conception of the position of the
historian and his limitations and pos-

The author of numerous books
and poems, Dr. Abercrombie is distinguished in the fields of poetry and
literary criticism. Dr. Lovejoy, of the
Hopkins, has heard Dr. Abercrombie
speak and says that he is excellent
as a lecturer. Dr. Raymond W.
Chambers of University College,
London, has only the highest praise
for Dr. Abercrombie's books.
The one-hour lectures are to be
given in Latrobe Hall, beginning at

Dr.David Robinson
Returns From Tour

Dr. David M. Robinson, professor
)f archaeology, last week returned
from a lecture tour of New England
Ind New York. The principal places
"here Dr. Robinson spoke were Boston, on March 5; Haverhill, on March
3; Vassar College, on March 7; and
Columbia University, on March 8.
The subject of Dr. Robinson's lectures was the recent excavations at
Dlynthus. He illustrated the lectures
with slides, many of which are of
Vecial interest to classical scholars
Is they have not been printed, due
L0 lack of funds for that purpose.
Or. Robinson will speak to a group
3f medical men on his experiences in
l'eece on March 17. He will also
Rtldress the History Department of
oucher College on April 8.

March 22 Deadline Set
For 'Hullabaloo Copy
The HullabaZoo has extended the
deadline for filing application to
receive copies until next Friday,
March 22. All those not appearing
at the Hullabaloo office before the
new deadline will not receive their
copy of the book.

any attempt at having a dance until
the banquet had been successfully
held. This plan met the approval of

the entire class.

Abrams, chairman of Student Activities Committee, presided over the
assembly.

More Music!

Listening to the barber shop's new
radio "whooping it up" with the latest "red hots" reminds us that the
Musical Club is putting on a concert of real music this evenlng. At
the end of a most successful season,
which has included a prodigious number of concerts all over this state and
neighboring ones, the Club looks
back on fifty-one years of being one
of the best recognized groups of amateur entertainers in the countryside.
In fact, in their fifty-one years of
being the oldest Hopkins organization, this group has come to be probably the most widely-recognized
and indubitably successful organizations on the campus. They may
be only a bunch of boys, but they
have what it takes!

that the Hopkins musicians let us

One of my stooges has brought the
following to my attention, and I, as
your faithful servant, hereby transmit it to you, dear readers, for all it
is worth.
Dr. Clifford Lyons, public speaking
instructor, and debating coach has a
novel system of checking lateness to
classes, by both students and himself.
Each time a student arrives after the
bell, he must deposit a nickel in the
kitty, and when Dr. Lyons is tardy,
he must part with a dime.
The sum at the end of the semester
is to go toward the purchase of Hershey Bars. One day last week Dr.
Lyons appeared after the bell had
rung, but alibied himself out of a fine,
by claiming that the tower clock was
only one minute to one.

Swimmers Defeat Villanova
And George Washington;
By KEN ZIERLER
New Records Set In 2 Tilts
A Little Story
May Enter S.A. Meet Of Success

Jay Walks

Several Hopkins Natators To
Keep In Shape Until April
5; Jay Relay Team Ready
With only the South Atlantics in
front of them, the Jay natators have
completed a rather

mediocre dual

meet season, dropping five of their
seven engagements. The Jays were
victorious only over Villanova and
George Washington, while they dropped encounters to Franklin and
Marshall, Lafayette, Delaware, Virginia, and Manhattan.
Although Hopkins did not show up
so well in the won and lost columns,
several individual performances were
outstanding, with two new records
being established. These were accounted for by Bill Hazlett and Johnny MacGill.
Hazlett set up a new mark in his
specialty, the 200-yard breaststroke,
in the Villanova contest, which the
Jays captured 30-20. Bill led home
the opposition by almost twenty yards
covering the distance in 2m. 47s. The
old record was held by Eddie Sadtler,
last year's captain, at 2:5 1-4. Hazlett was defeated in only two meets
this season, securing first places in
5 of the 7 engagements in which the
team participated.
Backstroke Mark Falls
The backstroke mark took a severe lacing, as three times a Jay natator succeeded in hitting a new low
for the event. While Johnny MacGill
accounted for the final time of 1:55.0.
Dan Weiner started the proceedings
with a 1:57 in the first meet of the
year with Lafayette, as compared
with the record of 1:59. Weiner's
time withstood the dorsal assaults
until the G. W. encounter, when MacGill stroked through to victory in
1:55.2.
The Hopkins high-point scorer was
Lou Adler, sprint star, who showed
great consistency throughout the
campaign. Adler made his best record in the 100-yard dash. obtaining
3 wins and 3 seconds in the 6 century
swims in which he competed. This
record, in addition to 15 points scored
in the 50-yard dash, accounted for his
high total of 42 markers.
Koenig, McConnell Star
Bill Koenig and Capt. Bill McConnell formed a consistent pair in the
diving, managing to secure at least
3 points in every engagement. The
former turned in a fine performance
against Manhattan, winning the event
by a narrow margin from Stadelberger, the New York ace.
Bill Bishop, Don Noonan, Charlie
Jones, Eddie Scheer, and Buddy Adler were the other Hopkins swimmers
who aided the team considerably
throughout the season. Bishop joined
up with Hazlett in the breaststroke,
and usually placed second to his teammate. Don Noonan, and Charlie Jones
competed for the Black and Blue in
the sprint and relay; Eddie Scheer
represented Hopkins in the 220 and
relay; while Bud Adler performed in
the 220 and 440-yard races.
Coach Hambleton's men inaugurated their season inauspiciously, succumbing to the Lafayette aggregation by the score of 44-24.
The
Black and Blue had received a severe
blow when Capt. Woody White left
school, and this occurrence, in addition to the fact that the team had
had insufficient practice, handicapped
Hopkins greatly in their meet with
the Quakers.
Manhattan Meet Close
Undoubtedly, the closest contest of
the year was the one with Manhattan. The Jays scored as many points
as their opponents, the final count
being 34-34, but in accordance with
Intercollegiate rules, the New Yorkers' victory in the relay automatically gave them the meet. The Black
and Blue captured the breaststroke,
backstroke and dive, Manhattan taking every free-style event.
It is undecided as to whether or not
Hopkins will put a complete squad in
the South Atlanticc, but several Jay
natators will definitely compete. Lou
Adler will swim in the sprints; Don
Weiner and John MacGill will team
up in the backstroke; and Bud Adler
will race in the 220. In all probability, a Jay relay team will be entered,
and several other Black and Blue
members are considering performing
In their specialties.

Dr. Shaffer told me last Saturday
afternoon he counted 250 people engaged in some sort of athletic activity in and around the gym at one
time. During the course of the afternoon there were probably 50 or so
more men in the gym, which means
that over a third of the undergraduate
enrollment was taking advantage of
the opportunities offered by the rerevamped administration.
I don't want to give the impression
of having deteriorated into a press
agent for these men (no implications
meant), but it must be pointed out
that this is really a magnificent
achievement. Effervescent and optimistic as fresh administrations always are at heart, the new Department of Physical Training and Athletics never hoped to realize such success the first year as that exemplified
by the statement in the previous paragraph.
It is by such concrete demonstrations of student interest as this that
athletic budgets are increased, that
provisions are made to equip more
men for more sports. But Hopkins,
hard-pressed financially, can increase
the athletic appropriations only to a
certain extent. The rest must come
from alumni contributions labeled exmust be some alumni interested in
pressly for an athletic fund. There
Jay sports and able to back up their
interest with something palpable.

Lean Years
Ahead?
Frank Dotterweich is in the process
of completing an ambitious and meaty
schedule for the yearling stickmen.
When completed, the schedule will
probably include about 12 games,
Frank says. This in itself is enough
to turn the varsity several shades of
green. But there is another point.
More out-of-town men than ever before have come out to learn something
about lacrosse. Most of them have
never even seen a lacrosse game, but,
impelled by a new spirit that has
made a democracy of athletics, they
have come out for a Hopkins team.
The enthusiasm that anyone who
plays the game is bound to get will
be carried by them back to their home
towns—to Passaic, to the Bronx, to
Brooklyn, to Newark, and so on. Clem
Spring, St. John's attack man of five
years ago, did that very thing. These
Hopkins men will do the same thing.
Lacrosse will take root in their home
town high schools, and pretty soon
the northern colleges will creep up
on Maryland.
This means that interest in varsity
lacrosse at Hopkins will have to be
strengthened. It is no secret that we
didn't get our fair share of local high
school stars this year. The reason was
the uncertainty of football here. Most

Lacrosse Body Considers New OutOf-Bounds Rules; Lotz And Mallonee Represent Hopkins
Several important changes were
discussed at a lacrosse rules interpretation meeting last Tuesday night.
The meeting was attended by noted
officials and coaches of Maryland colleges, including representatives from
Navy, Mt. Washington, Maryland and
Hopkins. Although head coach of lacrosse, Kelso Morrill, did not attend,
Hopkins was well represented by Ed
Lotz and Gardner Mallonee.
Some of the more important
changes follow:
1. If a player not participating in
the play goes off side, he is called
back on his side and not penalized.
2. A ball, going out of bounds on
the fly, shall go to the side opposite
the one that caused it to go out of
bounds.
3. A ball rolling out of bounds shall
be given to the man first reaching the
point where it went out of bounds.
It is hoped that these changes will
eliminate all former conflicts over the
interpretations of the former rules.

Dr. Trott Organizes League
Including Eight Teams;
Interest In Game Is Keen
A volleyball league, under the supervision of Dr. Richard Trott, has
been formed for graduate students
and teachers, and includes eight
teams.
Those that are competing are the
Mathematics, Geology, Engineer, Biology, Psychology History, Romance
Language, and Chemistry teams.
All of the players on the teams are
novices at the game but are rapidly
learning the fine points. Interest is
very keen and the league promises
to be a huge success.
Six games have been played already with the Geology team showing up the best.

Jays Enjoying Success, Despite Inexperience; Record
Is Two Wins, One Loss
The Johns Hopkins fencers will engage Penn State University in a meet
to take place this afternoon at 3:00
p. m. in the gym. The Nittany Lions
have a strong team this year and a
hard-fought match is expected.
Despite the fact that this is the
first year in which the Jaymen have
participated in intercollegiate fencing, the team has made a fine showing thus far. After losing their first
match to Delaware by a one-point
margin the Blue squad proceeded to
win their next two duels, defeating
Catholic University and St. John's
College.
The match scheduled last Friday between the Jays and Temple University was called off because of financial difficulties. There had been no
appropriation made for fencing in the
budget and, consequently, the guarantee which was offered to the Temple
swordsmen did not prove a sufficient
inducement.
Coach Paul Kaiss is still uncertain
about his starting lineup, but in all
probability, it will consist of the following men: Foils—Reed, Sherman,
Davis; Epee—Dyke, Peel; Sabre—
Peele, Waltzel.

BASEBALL MEETING
There will be a meeting of baseball enthusiasts this Saturday at
1:30 p. m. in the gym. Dr. Shaffer
will speak at the meeting.

"Historians will record 500 years
from now, I believe, that in the early
part of the twentieth century was
the greatest emancipatory revolution
in the history of the human race,"
said Dr. Charles A. Beard in his final
lecture given under the James Schouler Foundation Tuesday evening.

Dr. Lascelles Abercrombie, the
Hildred Carlisle professor of English
literature at Bedford College, of the
University of London, will deliver the
thirty-first in the series of Percy
Turnbull Memorial Lectures at the
Hopkins during the early part of
April. Dr. Abercrombie will speak on
"The Art of Wordsworth."

"An old era is closed forever, and
we 'are on the threshold of an entirely
new era," the historian said.
Monday he lectured on "History as
Art and Science," pointing out that
historians frequently have made the
mistake of drawing a close analogy
between history and art and science.
Tuesday, talking on "History
Speaks for Itself," Dr. Beard gave
his conception of the position of the
historian and his limitations and pos-

The author of numerous books
and poems, Dr. Abercrombie is distinguished in the fields of poetry and
literary criticism. Dr. Lovejoy, of the
Hopkins, has heard Dr. Abercrombie
speak and says that he is excellent
as a lecturer. Dr. Raymond W.
Chambers of University College,
London, has only the highest praise
for Dr. Abercrombie's books.
The one-hour lectures are to be
given in Latrobe Hall, beginning at

More Music!

Listening to the barber shop's new
radio "whooping it up" with the latest "red hots" reminds us that the
Musical Club is putting on a concert of real music this evenlng. At
the end of a most successful season,
which has included a prodigious number of concerts all over this state and
neighboring ones, the Club looks
back on fifty-one years of being one
of the best recognized groups of amateur entertainers in the countryside.
In fact, in their fifty-one years of
being the oldest Hopkins organization, this group has come to be probably the most widely-recognized
and indubitably successful organizations on the campus. They may
be only a bunch of boys, but they
have what it takes!
Our only suggestion, if we might
be allowed to make one, would be
that the Hopkins musicians let us
in on a little more of their work. Another entertainment or so per year

One of my stooges has brought the
following to my attention, and I, as
your faithful servant, hereby transmit it to you, dear readers, for all it
is worth.
Dr. Clifford Lyons, public speaking
instructor, and debating coach has a
novel system of checking lateness to
classes, by both students and himself.
Each time a student arrives after the
bell, he must deposit a nickel in the
kitty, and when Dr. Lyons is tardy,
he must part with a dime.
The sum at the end of the semester
is to go toward the purchase of Hershey Bars. One day last week Dr.
Lyons appeared after the bell had
rung, but alibied himself out of a fine,
by claiming that the tower clock was
only one minute to one.

Swimmers Defeat Villanova
And George Washington;
By KEN ZIERLER
New Records Set In 2 Tilts
A Little Story
May Enter S.A. Meet Of Success

Jay Walks

Several Hopkins Natators To
Keep In Shape Until April
5; Jay Relay Team Ready
With only the South Atlantics in
front of them, the Jay natators have
completed a rather

mediocre dual

meet season, dropping five of their
seven engagements. The Jays were
victorious only over Villanova and
George Washington, while they dropped encounters to Franklin and
Marshall, Lafayette, Delaware, Virginia, and Manhattan.
Although Hopkins did not show up
so well in the won and lost columns,
several individual performances were
outstanding, with two new records
being established. These were accounted for by Bill Hazlett and Johnny MacGill.
Hazlett set up a new mark in his
specialty, the 200-yard breaststroke,
in the Villanova contest, which the
Jays captured 30-20. Bill led home
the opposition by almost twenty yards
covering the distance in 2m. 47s. The
old record was held by Eddie Sadtler,
last year's captain, at 2:5 1-4. Hazlett was defeated in only two meets
this season, securing first places in
5 of the 7 engagements in which the
team participated.
Backstroke Mark Falls
The backstroke mark took a severe lacing, as three times a Jay natator succeeded in hitting a new low
for the event. While Johnny MacGill
accounted for the final time of 1:55.0.
Dan Weiner started the proceedings
with a 1:57 in the first meet of the
year with Lafayette, as compared
with the record of 1:59. Weiner's
time withstood the dorsal assaults
until the G. W. encounter, when MacGill stroked through to victory in
1:55.2.
The Hopkins high-point scorer was
Lou Adler, sprint star, who showed
great consistency throughout the
campaign. Adler made his best record in the 100-yard dash. obtaining
3 wins and 3 seconds in the 6 century
swims in which he competed. This
record, in addition to 15 points scored
in the 50-yard dash, accounted for his
high total of 42 markers.
Koenig, McConnell Star
Bill Koenig and Capt. Bill McConnell formed a consistent pair in the
diving, managing to secure at least
3 points in every engagement. The
former turned in a fine performance
against Manhattan, winning the event
by a narrow margin from Stadelberger, the New York ace.
Bill Bishop, Don Noonan, Charlie
Jones, Eddie Scheer, and Buddy Adler were the other Hopkins swimmers
who aided the team considerably
throughout the season. Bishop joined
up with Hazlett in the breaststroke,
and usually placed second to his teammate. Don Noonan, and Charlie Jones
competed for the Black and Blue in
the sprint and relay; Eddie Scheer
represented Hopkins in the 220 and
relay; while Bud Adler performed in
the 220 and 440-yard races.
Coach Hambleton's men inaugurated their season inauspiciously, succumbing to the Lafayette aggregation by the score of 44-24.
The
Black and Blue had received a severe
blow when Capt. Woody White left
school, and this occurrence, in addition to the fact that the team had
had insufficient practice, handicapped
Hopkins greatly in their meet with
the Quakers.
Manhattan Meet Close
Undoubtedly, the closest contest of
the year was the one with Manhattan. The Jays scored as many points
as their opponents, the final count
being 34-34, but in accordance with
Intercollegiate rules, the New Yorkers' victory in the relay automatically gave them the meet. The Black
and Blue captured the breaststroke,
backstroke and dive, Manhattan taking every free-style event.
It is undecided as to whether or not
Hopkins will put a complete squad in
the South Atlanticc, but several Jay
natators will definitely compete. Lou
Adler will swim in the sprints; Don
Weiner and John MacGill will team
up in the backstroke; and Bud Adler
will race in the 220. In all probability, a Jay relay team will be entered,
and several other Black and Blue
members are considering performing
In their specialties.

Dr. Shaffer told me last Saturday
afternoon he counted 250 people engaged in some sort of athletic activity in and around the gym at one
time. During the course of the afternoon there were probably 50 or so
more men in the gym, which means
that over a third of the undergraduate
enrollment was taking advantage of
the opportunities offered by the rerevamped administration.
I don't want to give the impression
of having deteriorated into a press
agent for these men (no implications
meant), but it must be pointed out
that this is really a magnificent
achievement. Effervescent and optimistic as fresh administrations always are at heart, the new Department of Physical Training and Athletics never hoped to realize such success the first year as that exemplified
by the statement in the previous paragraph.
It is by such concrete demonstrations of student interest as this that
athletic budgets are increased, that
provisions are made to equip more
men for more sports. But Hopkins,
hard-pressed financially, can increase
the athletic appropriations only to a
certain extent. The rest must come
from alumni contributions labeled exmust be some alumni interested in
pressly for an athletic fund. There

interest with something palpable.

Lean Years
Ahead?
Frank Dotterweich is in the process
of completing an ambitious and meaty
schedule for the yearling stickmen.
When completed, the schedule will
probably include about 12 games,
Frank says. This in itself is enough
to turn the varsity several shades of
green. But there is another point.
More out-of-town men than ever before have come out to learn something
about lacrosse. Most of them have
never even seen a lacrosse game, but,
impelled by a new spirit that has
made a democracy of athletics, they
have come out for a Hopkins team.
The enthusiasm that anyone who
plays the game is bound to get will
be carried by them back to their home
towns—to Passaic, to the Bronx, to
Brooklyn, to Newark, and so on. Clem
Spring, St. John's attack man of five
years ago, did that very thing. These
Hopkins men will do the same thing.
Lacrosse will take root in their home
town high schools, and pretty soon
the northern colleges will creep up
on Maryland.
This means that interest in varsity
lacrosse at Hopkins will have to be
strengthened. It is no secret that we
didn't get our fair share of local high
school stars this year. The reason was
the uncertainty of football here. Most
lacrosse men are also football men.
They would like to play the grid game
in college as well as lacrosse. Jay
football was dangling in mid-air this
past summer, so the lacrosse men who
wanted their football, too, went some
place else.

Lacrosse Body Considers New OutOf-Bounds Rules; Lotz And Mallonee Represent Hopkins
Several important changes were
discussed at a lacrosse rules interpretation meeting last Tuesday night.
The meeting was attended by noted
officials and coaches of Maryland colleges, including representatives from
Navy, Mt. Washington, Maryland and
Hopkins. Although head coach of lacrosse, Kelso Morrill, did not attend,
Hopkins was well represented by Ed
Lotz and Gardner Mallonee.
Some of the more important
changes follow:
1. If a player not participating in
the play goes off side, he is called
back on his side and not penalized.
2. A ball, going out of bounds on
the fly, shall go to the side opposite
the one that caused it to go out of
bounds.
3. A ball rolling out of bounds shall
be given to the man first reaching the
point where it went out of bounds.
It is hoped that these changes will
eliminate all former conflicts over the
interpretations of the former rules.

Grad Volleyball
League Formed
Dr. Trott Organizes League
Including Eight Teams;
Interest In Game Is Keen
A volleyball league, under the supervision of Dr. Richard Trott, has
been formed for graduate students
and teachers, and includes eight
teams.
Those that are competing are the
Mathematics, Geology, Engineer, Biology, Psychology History, Romance
Language, and Chemistry teams.
All of the players on the teams are
novices at the game but are rapidly
learning the fine points. Interest is
very keen and the league promises
to be a huge success.
Six games have been played already with the Geology team showing up the best.

Jays Enjoying Success, Despite Inexperience; Record
Is Two Wins, One Loss
The Johns Hopkins fencers will engage Penn State University in a meet
to take place this afternoon at 3:00
p. m. in the gym. The Nittany Lions
have a strong team this year and a
hard-fought match is expected.
Despite the fact that this is the
first year in which the Jaymen have
participated in intercollegiate fencing, the team has made a fine showing thus far. After losing their first
match to Delaware by a one-point
margin the Blue squad proceeded to
win their next two duels, defeating
Catholic University and St. John's
College.
The match scheduled last Friday between the Jays and Temple University was called off because of financial difficulties. There had been no
appropriation made for fencing in the
budget and, consequently, the guarantee which was offered to the Temple
swordsmen did not prove a sufficient
inducement.
Coach Paul Kaiss is still uncertain
about his starting lineup, but in all
probability, it will consist of the following men: Foils—Reed, Sherman,
Davis; Epee—Dyke, Peel; Sabre—
Peele, Waltzel.

BASEBALL MEETING
There will be a meeting of baseball enthusiasts this Saturday at
1:30 p. m. in the gym. Dr. Shaffer
will speak at the meeting.

Maryland Already Arranged;

shoulder-to-shoulder
match
with
